Overview Pre-lecture Lecture Explicit Algorithms Debunk Fallacies Empirical Foundation Post-lecture Impact

Zajac Teaching Portfolio

Lecture

Lectures introduce explicit algorithms for solving problems. Furthermore, lectures debunk common fallacies and provide an empirical foundation for theories and formulæ. This approach is supported by a review of Physics Education Research.

Explicit Algorithms

This excerpt from an actual lecture introduces an algorithm for Lenz's Law. Students will need this algorithm for tutorial, homework and test questions that follow. There may be some delay while the video loads.

Debunk Fallacies

This excerpt from an actual lecture debunks the fallacy that a battery maintains constant current — a mistaken belief held by many students. A reminder that temperature reflects atomic motion suggests, for students, that ϱ in R = ϱL/A must embody (temperature-dependent) microscopic properties of a conducting material. The meanings of L and A are covered in the next lecture except. There may be some delay while the video loads.

Empirical Foundation

This excerpt from an actual lecture provides empirical context for a discussion of resistance. To explain R = ϱ L / A as the relevant formula, L and A are introduced as the dimensions of play-dough sausages, from the pre-lecture video. The meaning of ϱ is covered in the previous lecture excerpt. There may be some delay while the video loads.
